choices.text: It has fewer side effects compared to other inhaled steroids
It is a prodrug metabolized by bronchial esterases
Occurrence of oral candidiasis is more compared to other inhaled steroids

questions.text: A child is started on ciclesonide inhalational therapy for bronchial asthma. Which of the following statements regarding this treatment is incorrect?
questions.solution:
• Ciclesonide is a unique corticosteroid (Prodrug) that, when inhaled, is converted into its active form in the lungs by bronchial esterases, allowing for targeted action within the airways.
  • It has lower oral bioavailability compared to other inhaled steroids, which reduces systemic & local side effects like oral candidiasis.

Inhaled Corticosteroids:

  • Inhaled corticosteroids are used in long-term maintenance therapy for chronic asthma, helping to control persistent inflammation.
  • For acute exacerbations that are not controlled by inhalational corticosteroids and bronchodilators, systemic corticosteroids (oral or IV) are used to rapidly reduce inflammation despite the fact that corticosteroids are not bronchodilators.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman on erythromycin for a respiratory infection presents with sudden syncope. ECG shows prolonged QT interval and Torsades de Pointes. She had recently taken an over-the-counter drug for allergies. Which of the following drugs, if added to erythromycin, most likely precipitated her condition?
questions.solution:
Astemizole is an antihistamine that has been associated with QT interval prolongation and the risk of Torsades de Pointes (TdP), especially when combined with drugs like erythromycin, which also prolong the QT interval.


Magnesium sulphate is the drug of choice for TdP, regardless of serum magnesium levels. It blocks L-type calcium channels in the heart, preventing EADs and interrupting the arrhythmia, but it does not shorten the QT interval on an ECG.

Doxylamine (Option A): Sedating antihistamine with minimal QT-prolonging effect; less likely to cause Torsades.

Loratadine (Option C): Second-generation antihistamine with a low risk of QT prolongation.

Promethazine (Option D): Primarily causes sedation and anticholinergic effects; rarely associated with significant QT prolongation.

questions.text: In which phase of clinical trials is drug dosing typically determined?
questions.solution:
• Drug dosing is typically determined during Phase 1 of clinical trials.
  • This phase is primarily focused on evaluating the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics (how the drug is absorbed, distributed, metabolized, and excreted) of the drug in humans.
  • During Phase 1 trials, healthy volunteers are given varying doses of the drug to observe how it is processed in the body and to identify any potential side effects.
  • The goal is to establish a safe dosage range for further trials.

questions.text: Methotrexate usage causes reduced synthesis of:
questions.solution:
• Methotrexate is a folate analogue that inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR).
  • DHFR is crucial for the conversion of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate, a cofactor required for the synthesis of thymidylate (TMP), which is necessary for DNA synthesis.
  • By inhibiting this enzyme, methotrexate reduces the synthesis of TMP, leading to impaired DNA synthesis, particularly affecting rapidly dividing cells.
  • Methotrexate does not directly inhibit the synthesis of CMP, GMP, or AMP to the same extent.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient stopped antihypertensive medication due to dry eyes, dry mouth and constipation. After stopping the drug, he developed a hypertensive emergency (BP > 180/120). The most likely drug is?
questions.solution:
• Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to treat hypertension. It works by decreasing sympathetic outflow, which lowers blood pressure.
  • When clonidine is stopped abruptly, it can lead to a rebound increase in blood pressure (Withdrawal syndrome), potentially causing a hypertensive emergency.
  • Withdrawal syndrome is characterized by various symptoms, including headache, apprehension, tremors, abdominal pain, sweating, and tachycardia.
    • Typically, this occurs 18 to 36 hours after stopping the medication
    • Management: Resume Clonidine administration and Phentolamine is considered the drug of choice for a hypertensive crisis

Lisinopril (Option B) is an ACE inhibitor used to treat hypertension and heart failure. Discontinuing lisinopril does not typically lead to rebound hypertension. Common side effects include cough and elevated potassium levels, but dry eyes, dry mouth, or constipation are not associated with lisinopril. Thus, a hypertensive emergency after stopping lisinopril is unlikely.

Amlodipine (Option C) is a calcium channel blocker commonly used to manage hypertension and angina. Amlodipine does not cause rebound hypertension when stopped. Its side effects can include swelling, dizziness, and flushing, but dry eyes, dry mouth, or constipation are not common. Therefore, stopping amlodipine would not typically lead to a hypertensive emergency.

Telmisartan (Option D) is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB). Similar to lisinopril, discontinuing telmisartan does not cause rebound hypertension. Common side effects include dizziness and hyperkalemia but not dry eyes, dry mouth, or constipation. A hypertensive emergency is unlikely to occur with the abrupt discontinuation of telmisartan.

Learning Objective:

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient is receiving a combination of antiretroviral therapy, including Zidovudine, Lamivudine, and Nevirapine, for HIV management. Which of the following drugs should be avoided due to potential drug interactions with this regimen?
questions.solution:
• Rifampicin is an enzyme inducer and can accelerate the metabolism of antiretroviral drugs like Zidovudine, Lamivudine, and Nevirapine, reducing their effectiveness.
  • It should be avoided or used with caution in patients receiving these medications. Streptomycin, INH (Isoniazid), and Ethambutol do not have significant interactions and are considered safe to use.

Reference: Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome

questions.text: Which anticoagulant is recommended for a pregnant female at 29 weeks of gestation who develops deep vein thrombosis (DVT) with calf tenderness, diagnosed via Doppler ultrasound?
questions.solution:
• Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), such as enoxaparin, is the preferred anticoagulant for treating DVT in pregnancy.
  • It is safe, does not cross the placenta, and has a lower risk of causing heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) than unfractionated heparin.
  • LMWH is also effective in preventing the extension of the thrombus and reducing the risk of pulmonary embolism, making it the standard treatment for DVT during pregnancy.

Learning Objective:


Reference: Antiphospholipid Syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following chelators is contraindicated in iron poisoning?
questions.solution: BAL (Dimercaprol) is a chelator primarily used to treat poisoning by heavy metals such as arsenic, mercury, and lead. However, it is contraindicated in iron poisoning because it does not effectively bind to iron. In fact, it may displace iron from its binding sites, potentially worsening the toxicity. Therefore, using BAL in iron poisoning could exacerbate the condition rather than alleviate it.

questions.text: Identify the drug marked as "X" in the given image.
questions.solution:
Amino-caproic acid is an antifibrinolytic agent that works by inhibiting the activation of plasminogen to plasmin, thus preventing the breakdown of fibrin in blood clots.


Clopidogrel (Option A) is an antiplatelet agent that prevents platelet aggregation by inhibiting the ADP receptor on platelets. It does not affect the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin.

Tenecteplase (Option C) is a thrombolytic agent that facilitates the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, promoting the breakdown of clots. It is the opposite of Amino-caproic acid in terms of its action.

Heparin (Option D) is an anticoagulant that works by inhibiting thrombin and factor Xa to prevent clot formation, but it does not directly affect the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin.

questions.text: Lignocaine (lidocaine) is used as a loading dose for the treatment of arrhythmias. The loading dose depends on which of the following factors?
questions.solution:
The loading dose of a drug depends upon the volume of distribution:

  • A drug's loading dose is given to achieve a target plasma concentration quickly when the treatment requires an immediate therapeutic response.
  • Loading dose depends on the volume of distribution of a drug

Learning Objective:

  • Maintenance dose mainly depends on the clearance/plasma half-life of a drug.

questions.text: A patient with a previous MI and ventricular arrhythmia is on treatment for a few months. He developed fatigue, dyspnea and weight gain. He had also developed pulmonary fibrosis. Which of the following drugs is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Amiodarone, a potassium channel blocker and class 3 anti-arrhythmic drug, is used to treat both atrial and ventricular fibrillation. It may cause side effects such as fatigue, dyspnea, weight gain, and, with prolonged use, pulmonary fibrosis.


Atenolol (Option B) is a beta-blocker used for managing hypertension, stable heart failure, post-myocardial infarction (to prevent sudden cardiac death), and the prevention of left ventricular hypertrophy. Side effects include fatigue, reduced libido, cognitive issues, nightmares, bradycardia, hypotension, rebound hypertension, aggravated ischemia, angina, MI, and increased triglycerides/LDL.

Aspirin (Option C) is an antiplatelet medication that irreversibly inhibits COX-1, thereby preventing platelet aggregation. It is the drug of choice for myocardial infarction (MI), stroke, and Buerger's disease.

Spironolactone (Option D) is a potassium-sparing diuretic that either inhibits sodium channels in the distal nephron or blocks aldosterone receptors. It is used to treat heart failure and hyperaldosteronism. Side effects include hyperkalemia and gynecomastia.

choices.text: N-acetyl cysteine to replenish glutathione stores
Glucagon to control bradycardia and hypoglycemia
Give sodium bicarbonate to alkalize urine

questions.text: A young female comes to the emergency department after consuming 100 aspirin tablets. What should be the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is a case of aspirin toxicity in which the primary treatment is to give sodium bicarbonate in order to alkalize the urine.

  • It is an antiplatelet medication that irreversibly inhibits COX-1, thereby preventing platelet aggregation.
  • Aspirin stimulates the brain's respiratory center, causing hyperventilation (↓CO2 levels) and respiratory alkalosis.
  • The kidneys excrete more bicarbonate to counteract respiratory alkalosis, resulting in metabolic acidosis (Compensatory metabolic acidosis). High doses of aspirin can disrupt oxidative phosphorylation and kidney function, exacerbating metabolic acidosis.

Dosage and Toxicity:

  • Therapeutic Dose: 3-5 g/day can cause mild chronic toxicity (salicylism).
  • Toxic Dose: Acute ingestion of 10-30 g in adults can be lethal, with much lower doses (4 mL of methyl salicylate) posing a significant risk in children

Clinical presentation:

  • Salicylism: Headache, dizziness, tinnitus, reversible hearing and vision impairment, drowsiness, vomiting, hyperventilation, electrolyte imbalance
  • Severe toxicity: Dehydration, high tone deafness, confusion, petechial haemorrhages, hyperpyrexia, seizures, hypoglycemia, psychosis, coma

Management: Treatment is supportive and includes gastric lavage, correction of metabolic acidosis, vitamin K supplements and urinary alkalinization with intravenous sodium bicarbonate to enhance salicylate excretion. In severe cases, hemodialysis may be necessary.

Learning Objective:

High-dose aspirin causes respiratory alkalosis (stimulates the brain's respiratory center) & metabolic acidosis (Increases bicarbonate excretion and disrupts oxidative phosphorylation)

Management of aspirin toxicity: Urinary alkalinization with intravenous sodium bicarbonate and vitamin K supplements, and in severe cases, hemodialysis may be necessary.

N-acetyl cysteine to replenish glutathione stores (Option A) is not indicated in the management of aspirin overdose. It is used as an antidote for acetaminophen overdose, which can cause liver toxicity by depleting glutathione stores. Aspirin overdose does not cause glutathione depletion, so N-acetyl cysteine is not useful in this situation.

Pralidoxime (Option B) is not indicated in the management of aspirin overdose. Pralidosime is an antidote for organophosphate poisoning, which can cause cholinergic toxicity by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase activity. Aspirin overdose does not cause cholinergic toxicity, so this option is not used here.

Glucagon to control bradycardia and hypoglycemia (Option C): Glucagon is not indicated in the management of aspirin overdose. Glucagon is used as an antidote to beta-blocker toxicity.

questions.text: A physician prescribed a drug that reduces the synthesis of uric acid for the gout. Identify the drug
questions.solution:
• Allopurinol is an inhibitor of xanthine oxidase (XO).
  • Both allopurinol and its primary metabolite, oxypurinol (alloxanthine), reduce urate production by inhibiting XO, the enzyme that converts xanthine to uric acid.
  • Allopurinol competitively inhibits XO at low concentrations and is a non-competitive inhibitor at high concentrations.
  • It is the drug of choice for the treatment of chronic gout.
  • Other uses of allopurinol:
    • Tumour lysis syndrome
    • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome
    • Post-transplant patients

Probenecid (Option A) is a uricosuric agent that acts by increasing uric acid's excretion in the urine.

Colchicine (Option B) is an anti-inflammatory medication commonly used to treat acute gout attacks but doesn't affect uric acid levels.

Diclofenac (Option C) is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that can also be used to manage gout symptoms but does not inhibit uric acid synthesis.

Learning Objective:

questions.text: A patient was given digoxin and started having side effects like nausea and vomiting. The serum concentration of digoxin was 4 ng/ml, and the plasma therapeutic range was 1 ng/ml. If the half-life of digoxin is 40 hours, what time is required till you can safely start digoxin again?
questions.solution:
• The Plasma half-life (t½) of a drug is the time taken for its plasma concentration to be reduced to half of its original value.
  • In the scenario, the digoxin serum concentration of 4 ng/ml is significantly above the therapeutic range.

Starting at 4 ng/mL, it would take:

  • 1 half-life (40 hrs) → 2 ng/mL
  • 2 half-lives (80 hrs) → 1 ng/mL (within therapeutic range)

Since the therapeutic range is ≤1 ng/mL, the drug can be safely restarted after 80 hours.

Therefore, we should wait at least 80 hours before resuming treatment, considering digoxin's half-life of 40 hours.

questions.text: A patient presented with anxiety, restlessness, tremors and fever. His BP is 180/110 mmHg and atrial fibrillation is detected on ECG. He also has a history of asthma. What drug should be given next?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with clinical features of thyroid storm, including anxiety, tremors, fever, and atrial fibrillation on ECG, along with severe hypertension (BP 180/110 mmHg). The presence of asthma influences the choice of treatment.

Diltiazem is the preferred choice for rate control in an asthmatic patient with atrial fibrillation secondary to a thyroid storm.

Management priorities in thyroid storm with atrial fibrillation focus on:

  • Controlling heart rate and rhythm:
    • Diltiazem, a calcium channel blocker, is preferred in this case as it effectively slows AV node conduction and does not cause bronchoconstriction, making it safe for patients with asthma.
    • Beta-blockers such as esmolol or propranolol (Options A and B) are usually first-line but are contraindicated in asthmatic patients due to their risk of bronchospasm.
  • Reducing thyroid hormone synthesis:
    • Propylthiouracil (PTU) (Option C) is the drug of choice for inhibiting thyroid hormone synthesis in thyroid storm, but it does not address the immediate need to control atrial fibrillation and hypertension.

Learning Objective:

Management of thyroid storm:

  • Large doses of propylthiouracil (500-1000 mg loading dose and 250 mg every 4 h) should be given orally or by nasogastric tube or per rectum; the drug's inhibitory action on T4 → T3 conversion makes it the antithyroid drug of choice.
  • If not available, methimazole can be used in doses of 20 mg every 6 h.
  • One hour after the first dose of propylthiouracil, stable iodide (5 drops SSKI every 6 h) is given to block thyroid hormone synthesis via the Wolff-Chaikoff effect (the delay allows the antithyroid drug to prevent the excess iodine from being incorporated into new hormone).
  • Propranolol should also be given to reduce tachycardia and other adrenergic manifestations (60-80 mg PO every 4 h, or 2 mg IV every 4 h). Although other β-adrenergic blockers can be used, high doses of propranolol decrease T4 → T3 conversion and the doses can be easily adjusted.
  • Short-acting IV esmolol can be used to decrease heart rate while monitoring for signs of heart failure.
  • Additional therapeutic measures include glucocorticoids (e.g., hydrocortisone 300 mg IV bolus, then 100 mg every 8 h), antibiotics if infection is present, cholestyramine to sequester thyroid hormones, cooling, oxygen, and IV fluids.

questions.text: A patient with a malignancy is undergoing chemotherapy; his platelet counts were reduced during the previous cycle of chemotherapy. What will you give to prevent/treat this condition?
questions.solution:
• Oprelvekin (IL-11) is a medication used to stimulate platelet production in patients who have undergone chemotherapy.
  • It works by stimulating the production of megakaryocytes, which are the cells that produce platelets.
  • It is approved for use in patients with chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia (CIT), a condition characterized by a low platelet count caused by chemotherapy.

Filgrastim (Option B) is a medication used to stimulate the production of white blood cells in patients undergoing chemotherapy. It works by stimulating the bone marrow to produce more white blood cells, which can help to prevent infections. While low platelet counts can be a side effect of chemotherapy, filgrastim is not indicated for treating thrombocytopenia.

Erythropoietin (Option C) is a medication that stimulates red blood cell production in patients with anemia. It is not indicated for the treatment of thrombocytopenia.

Amifostine (Option D) is a medication used to protect healthy cells from the toxic effects of chemotherapy. It does not stimulate the production of platelets and is not indicated for the treatment of thrombocytopenia.

Learning Objective:

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented with rhinitis and facial swelling. An intranasal biopsy revealed the presence of broad-based aseptate hyphae with branching at the right angle. Evidence of vascular invasion was present. What will be the drug of choice
questions.solution:
The presence of broad-based aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching and evidence of vascular invasion suggests an infection caused by Rhizopus arrhizus, a group of fungi commonly responsible for mucormycosis.

The first-line treatment for mucormycosis is Amphotericin B (broad-spectrum antifungal).

Fluconazole (Option A) is a triazole antifungal that inhibits fungal ergosterol synthesis, but it is not effective against mucormycosis. It is effective against other fungal species like Candida, Cryptococcus, and Histoplasma.

Ketoconazole (Option C) is a broad-spectrum antifungal that is effective against many types of fungi like Candida species but not effective in treating mucormycosis.

Griseofulvin (Option B) is used to treat superficial fungal infections of skin, hair and nails, but it does not work against systemic or invasive fungal infections like mucormycosis.

questions.text: A woman presenting with symptoms of urinary tract infection was prescribed a drug that causes tendon rupture and arthropathy. What is the mechanism of action of the drug?
questions.solution:
• The drug in the given scenario is likely fluoroquinolone, which is known to cause side effects such as tendon rupture and arthropathy, especially in older adults.
  • These are commonly used to treat UTIs, respiratory infections and other bacterial infections.
  • Examples of fluoroquinolones:
    • Ciprofloxacin
    • Levofloxacin
    • Moxifloxacin
  • Fluoroquinolones inhibit DNA gyrase, which has a role in the synthesis of collagen, the primary structural protein and tendons, tendons and other connective tissues in tendons, which leads to weakened and damaged connective tissues in the tendons and joints.

Adverse effects of fluoroquinolones:

  • Gastrointestinal disturbances (nausea, diarrhoea).
  • CNS effects (headache, dizziness).
  • Tendonitis and tendon rupture.
  • QT interval prolongation.
  • Photosensitivity
  • Potential for exacerbation of myasthenia gravis.

Ribosomal inhibition (Option B): Ribosomal inhibitors, like macrolides, tetracyclines, and aminoglycosides, inhibit bacterial protein synthesis. These drugs do not cause tendon rupture or arthropathy.

Cell wall synthesis (Option C): Drugs like penicillins and cephalosporins inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis by targeting penicillin-binding proteins. These antibiotics are not associated with tendon rupture.

Inhibition of folic acid synthesis (Option D): Drugs like sulfonamides and trimethoprim inhibit folic acid synthesis in bacteria. These drugs do not cause tendon rupture or arthropathy.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with rigidity and tremors. On examination, he has blank facial expressions. Which of the following drugs can be used to manage this?
questions.solution:
• The elderly man presents with symptoms suggestive of Parkinson's disease, which commonly involves rigidity, tremors, and bradykinesia, along with blank facial expressions (a feature known as "masked facies").
  • In Parkinson's disease, the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra results in decreased dopamine levels in the striatum, leading to motor symptoms such as rigidity and tremors.
  • Selegiline is a monoamine oxidase type B (MAO-B) inhibitor that helps increase dopamine levels by inhibiting the breakdown of dopamine in the brain, thereby improving the motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease.
  • It is commonly used as adjunctive therapy with levodopa/carbidopa in the treatment of Parkinson's disease.
  • It is especially useful in the early stages of Parkinson's disease, where the benefits of levodopa/carbidopa alone are insufficient to control symptoms.

Clozapine (Option A) is an atypical antipsychotic that is primarily used to treat schizophrenia and other severe psychiatric disorders. It has dopamine receptor antagonistic effects, which can actually worsen symptoms of Parkinson's disease.

Donepezil (Option B) is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used to treat Alzheimer's disease by increasing acetylcholine levels in the brain. It is not effective for treating the motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease.

Haloperidol (Option D) is a typical antipsychotic that blocks dopamine receptors. It is used to treat schizophrenia and acute psychosis, but it can worsen Parkinsonian symptoms because of its dopamine antagonism.

questions.text: A female presented with a headache associated with photophobia and phonophobia. Which of the following drugs can be used for immediate relief?
questions.solution:
• The symptoms described as headache with photophobia (sensitivity to light) and phonophobia (sensitivity to sound) are consistent with For immediate relief of a migraine attack, the drug of choice is typically a triptan.
  • Sumatriptan is a 5-HT1B/1D Agonist (a triptan) and is used for acute treatment of migraine attacks and cluster headaches.

Learning objective:

Severity Classification of Migraine:

Migraine severity can be assessed using tools like the Migraine Disability Assessment Scale (MIDAS), which categorizes migraines as follows:

  • Grade 1: Little or no disability
  • Grade 2: Mild disability
  • Grade 3: Moderate disability
  • Grade 4: Serious disability

Acute Treatment (Abortive Therapy)

  1. Mild to Moderate Migraine (Grades 1-2)
    • Over-the-Counter Pain Relievers: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen or naproxen.
    • Triptans: Medications like sumatriptan or rizatriptan are effective for moderate migraines and should be taken at the onset of symptoms.
  2. Moderate to Severe Migraine (Grade 3-4)
    • Triptans: Higher doses or different formulations (e.g., nasal sprays, injections) may be necessary.
    • Dihydroergotamine: Effective for longer-lasting migraines; available as a nasal spray or injection.
    • Gepants: Ubrogepant and Rimegepant are newer oral medications that can relieve pain and associated symptoms like nausea.
    • Lasmiditan: An oral medication that can help with pain relief but may cause sedation.
  3. Status Migrainosus (Severe, prolonged attacks lasting over 72 hours)
    • Requires immediate medical attention.
    • Treatment may include intravenous fluids, anti-nausea medications, and possibly corticosteroids or stronger analgesics in a hospital setting.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should not be consumed by a patient with bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis currently on metronidazole?
questions.solution:
Patients taking metronidazole should not consume alcohol due to the risk of developing a Disulfiram-like reaction due to metronidazole.

Metronidazole, when consumed along with alcohol, causes a disulfiram-like reaction, which can present with abdominal distress, vomiting, flushing, psychosis and headache.

Grapefruit Juice (Option A) does not interact with Metronidazole and is considered safe to be consumed concurrently.

Benzodiazepines (Option C) are used to treat insomnia, anxiety and other psychiatric conditions, and there are no specific interactions between metronidazole and benzodiazepines.

MAO/SSRI (Option D) are antidepressant agents, and there are no specific interactions between metronidazole and benzodiazepines.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used to treat open-angle glaucoma in a patient with bronchial asthma?
questions.solution:
Latanoprost is a prostaglandin (PGF2α) analogue that is commonly used to lower intraocular pressure in open-angle glaucoma, and it can be used in patients with bronchial asthma as it is not associated with bronchospasm.

Timolol (Option B) is a non-selective beta-blocker that can be used topically to treat glaucoma but it is contraindicated in patients with asthma and COPD as it can have systemic side effects and lead to bronchospasm.

Gemeprost (Option C) is a PGE1 analogue that is used in the medical termination of pregnancy and not in glaucoma.

Mannitol infusion (Option D) is used to treat acute angle closure glaucoma as it causes decongestion of the eyes via its osmotic action. It is not used for open-angle glaucoma.

choices.text: Clearance of drug X desired peak plasma concentration

questions.text: What is the dosing rate of a drug based on?
questions.solution:
• The formula for drug dosing rate is Clearance of drug X desired peak plasma concentration.
  • The equation for dose rate is based on steady-state concentration. When a drug is given repeatedly at short intervals, it will accumulate in the body until the elimination of the drug matches the intake of the drug.
  • Thus, steady-state concentration is the plasma concentration at which drug elimination = drug intake.

questions.text: A patient presented with biliary colic to the ER. The intern administered an analgesic, which worsened the pain. Which of the following drugs could be responsible for aggravation of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
The drug which is likely to have aggravated the patient’s symptoms is Morphine.

Morphine/opioids are generally not advised for colicky pain due to the following reasons:

  • Morphine constricts the sphincter of Oddi, leading to increased pressure in the common bile duct.
  • Pressure can increase more than tenfold within 15 minutes of morphine administration.
  • Increased pressure may worsen biliary colic symptoms, causing epigastric distress and severe pain.
  • Pethidine can be used as it causes lesser spasms of the sphincter of Oddi.

Diclofenac (Option B), which is a non-opioid analgesic such as may be considered an alternative option for pain relief in these patients as it does not cause contraction of the sphincter of Oddi and can provide adequate pain relief.

Nefopam (Option C) is a centrally acting analgesic with muscle relaxant properties and is not known to cause sphincter Oddi contraction. However, it is not typically the first choice for managing biliary colic.

Etoricoxib (Option D) is a selective COX-2 inhibitor that can be considered as an alternative option for pain relief as it does not cause contraction of the sphincter of Oddi.

questions.text: Which of the following is an inhibitor of RNA synthesis?
questions.solution:
• Rifampicin is an inhibitor of RNA synthesis.
  • It binds to the beta subunit of DNA-dependent RNA-polymerase (rpoB) to form a stable drug-enzyme complex that suppresses the RNA chain formation in RNA synthesis.

5-Fluorouracil (Option A) inhibits thymidylate synthesis, which interferes with DNA synthesis.

Nitrofurantoin (Option C) produces highly reactive intermediates that cause DNA damage.

Novobiocin (Option D) is a potent inhibitor of bacterial DNA gyrase, which is involved in DNA replication.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding non-competitive inhibition?
questions.solution:
In non-competitive inhibition

  • Km remains same
  • Vmax decreases
  • Binds to both free enzyme and enzyme-substrate complexes with the same affinity.

Km increases and Vmax remains the same in competitive inhibition, where the inhibitor competes with the substrate for the active site.

Km decrease and Vmax increase do not occur in enzyme kinetics.

Km increases, Vmax increases cannot occur as inhibitors cannot increase Vmax.

questions.text: Calculate the therapeutic index of a drug whose dose-response curves are plotted as shown below:
questions.solution:
The Therapeutic Index of the given drug is calculated as 4.

In the graph given,

Median lethal dose (LD50) = 400 mg

Median effective dose (ED50) = 100

We know that,

Therapeutic index (TI)= LD50/ED50

400/100 = 4

Thus, the therapeutic index of the given drug is 4.

questions.text: What is the drug used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from cholinergic crisis?
questions.solution:
Edrophonium, a short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, is used as a diagnostic tool in suspected cases of Myasthenia Gravis.

Diagnosis of Myasthenia Gravis

Tensilon (edrophonium) Test

  • This involves the injection of 10 mg i.v. Edrophonium (a short-acting anticholinesterase agent) to individuals with a deficiency of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.
  • The drug works by temporarily increasing the levels of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, which improves muscle strength temporarily.
  • Steps:
    • 2 mg i.v. Edrophonium → Observe for any adverse reactions → If no adverse reactions occur after 30-60 seconds, the remaining 8 mg is injected.
  • Results:
    • Myasthenia Gravis: Short-lasting improvement in muscle strength.
    • Other Muscular Dystrophies: No improvement.
    • Cholinergic crisis: No improvement or a worsening of their condition.
  • If muscle strength improves after the administration of edrophonium, it indicates the presence of Myasthenia Gravis.

Alternative Test

  • If edrophonium is unavailable,1.5 mg of i.v. Neostigmine can be used alternatively.
  • Atropine (anticholinergic) pretreatment can be administered to counteract the muscarinic effects of neostigmine. (Option D)

Provocative test (d-Tubocurarine test)

  • Myasthenia gravis patients are highly sensitive to d-tubocurarine (a non-depolarising muscle blocker ); a 0.5 mg IV dose causes significant weakness in them but does not affect non-myasthenic individuals.
  • However, this test is hazardous and not commonly performed.

Obidoxime (Option A) is a cholinesterase reactivator. It is primarily used as an antidote in cases of poisoning caused by organophosphates and certain nerve agents, which inhibit acetylcholinesterase (an enzyme involved in breaking down acetylcholine).

Donepezil (Option C) is a cholinesterase inhibitor commonly used as a first-line treatment for managing symptoms of mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease. It works by increasing the levels of acetylcholine in the brain, which can help improve cognitive function and slow the progression of symptoms.

Learning Objective:

  • Edrophonium helps differentiate between myasthenic and cholinergic crises, which present with similar symptoms but require opposite treatments.
  • The cholinergic crisis results from excessive acetylcholine stimulation due to anticholinesterase medication overdose.

questions.text:
Which of the following diuretics matches its primary site of action correctly?
1. Osmotic diuretics - Distal convoluted tubule
2. Thiazide diuretics - Proximal convoluted tubule
3. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors - Proximal convoluted tubule
4. Potassium-sparing diuretics - Collecting duct
questions.solution:
• Osmotic diuretics primarily act in the proximal convoluted tubule and loop of Henle, not the distal convoluted tubule.
  • Thiazide diuretics act in the distal convoluted tubule, not the proximal convoluted tubule.
  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., Acetazolamide) act in the proximal convoluted tubule.
  • Potassium-sparing diuretics (e.g., Spironolactone, Amiloride) primarily act in the collecting duct.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient, after stopping the intake of alcohol, develops whole-body tremors along with vomiting and visual and auditory hallucinations. Which of the following is used to prevent another episode of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Chlordiazepoxide is a benzodiazepine commonly used to manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms, including tremors, anxiety, agitation, and seizures.
  • It works by enhancing the inhibitory effects of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) in the brain, which reduces neuronal excitability and calms the central nervous system.
  • This medication is long-acting and has self-tapering properties due to its active metabolites, making it effective for managing withdrawal over time.

BDZ used in Alcohol withdrawal:

  • Chlordiazepoxide
  • Clorazepate
  • Diazepam
  • Lorazepam
  • Midazolam
  • Oxazepam

Clonidine (Option B): While clonidine can help manage some symptoms of alcohol withdrawal, such as hypertension and agitation, it is not typically used as a first-line treatment for the full range of withdrawal symptoms, including tremors, vomiting, and hallucinations.

Topiramate (Option C) is an anticonvulsant that has been studied for reducing alcohol cravings and supporting abstinence in alcohol-dependent patients. However, it is not used to manage acute alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

Antabuse (Disulfiram) (Option D) is used to support the treatment of chronic alcoholism by causing an acute sensitivity to alcohol. It works by inhibiting acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to an accumulation of acetaldehyde when alcohol is consumed. However, it is not used for managing acute alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following topical antifungals is approved for the treatment of toenail onychomycosis?
questions.solution:
• Tavaborole is an oxaborole antifungal approved for the topical treatment of toenail onychomycosis.
  • It works by inhibiting fungal leucyl-tRNA synthetase, which disrupts protein synthesis and leads to fungal cell death.

Onychomycosis is a fungal nail infection, often caused by dermatophytes or Candida, and is best treated with systemic therapy. Fungal infection should be confirmed before starting treatment, as other conditions can mimic onychomycosis.

  • Systemic Treatments:
    • Terbinafine (250 mg daily for 6 weeks for fingernails, 12 weeks for toenails) is the most effective for dermatophyte onychomycosis.
    • Itraconazole (Option C) (200 mg daily for 6 weeks for fingernails, 12 weeks for toenails) is effective for both dermatophyte and candidal onychomycosis, with an option for pulsed dosing.
    • Fluconazole is an alternative for patients who cannot use terbinafine or itraconazole.
    • Griseofulvin (Option D) is less effective and no longer preferred due to longer treatment courses.
  • Topical Treatments:
    • Approved topical antifungals include ciclopirox lacquer, efinaconazole, and tavaborole, which require 48 weeks of treatment. These are used for mild-to-moderate cases or when systemic therapy is not suitable.

Caspofungin (Option A) is an echinocandin antifungal that is effective against Candida and Aspergillus infections. It is administered intravenously, not topically, and is not approved for onychomycosis.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs causes modulation of voltage-gated sodium channels by selectively enhancing slow inactivation?
questions.solution:
Lacosamide selectively enhances slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels, inhibiting high-frequency neuronal firing and reducing seizure activity.

Voltage-Gated Sodium Channels: Voltage-gated sodium channels play a key role in generating and propagating action potentials in neurons. These channels open in response to membrane depolarization, allowing Na+ to flow into the cell, leading to further depolarization.

  • Fast Inactivation Modulators:
    • Phenytoin (Option B)
    • Carbamazepine
  • Slow Inactivation Modulators:
    • Lacosamide

Lamotrigine (Option C) primarily affects sodium channels by inhibiting their ability to recover from both fast and slow inactivation. It is not as selective for enhancing slow inactivation, and while it reduces high-frequency firing, its primary action is broader, affecting both types of inactivation.

Ethosuximide (Option D) does not act on sodium channels. It primarily targets T-type calcium channels in the thalamus, which are involved in the generation of absence seizures. It does not directly modulate sodium channel inactivation.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2887460/

questions.text: A fall in diastolic blood pressure (BP) due to the loss of sympathetic outflow is mediated by which receptor?
questions.solution:
• The loss of sympathetic outflow leads to a decrease in diastolic blood pressure, which is primarily mediated by the Alpha 2 receptors.
  • These receptors are inhibitory and are involved in negative feedback mechanisms to reduce the release of norepinephrine from sympathetic nerve terminals, which in turn lowers blood pressure.

Receptor Effects on Blood Pressure:

  • Alpha 1: Vasoconstriction, increased BP.
  • Beta 1: Increased heart rate and contractility, increased BP.
  • Alpha 2: Decreased sympathetic outflow, decreased BP.
  • Beta 2: Vasodilation and bronchodilation, potentially lowering BP

questions.text: A patient with hemophilia on antiretroviral therapy is brought in with altered mental status following complaints of nausea, vomiting and headache. Which of the following medications was he taking?
questions.solution:
Tipranavir (Protease inhibitor) can cause altered mental status, headache, nausea, vomiting, and intracranial bleeding.


Tenofovir (Option A) is a nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) commonly used in antiretroviral therapy. While it can cause side effects like nephrotoxicity and bone mineral loss, it is not associated with an increased risk of intracranial hemorrhage or bleeding disorders.

Saquinavir (Option B) is incorrect as it does not affect blood vessels.

Darunavir (Option D) is a protease inhibitor that may cause gastrointestinal disturbances and metabolic abnormalities. However, it does not have a strong association with intracranial hemorrhage or bleeding risks.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with MDR tuberculosis presents with fatigue, constipation, weight gain, and neck swelling. Which of the following drugs is implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms suggest hypothyroidism, which can be due to ethionamide.

Ethionamide:

  • It acts similarly to isoniazid, a first-line anti-TB drug (group C drugs in MDR TB treatment).
  • Works by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acids, which are essential components of the bacterial cell wall of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • It is used to treat multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB).
  • It can cause hepatotoxicity and disrupt thyroid function, leading to these adverse effects.

Side effects:

  • Nausea, vomiting, and loss of appetite
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Neurological symptoms include peripheral neuropathy, dizziness, and confusion. These are treated with pyridoxine (Vitamin B6).
  • Erectile dysfunction
  • Hypothyroidism

Cycloserine (Option A) is associated with neurological and psychiatric side effects, such as depression, anxiety, psychosis, and seizures. It does not cause hypothyroidism or thyroid-related symptoms.

Streptomycin (Option C), an aminoglycoside, is primarily associated with ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity. It has no effect on thyroid function or related symptoms.

Pyrazinamide (Option D) is a first-line anti-TB drug linked to hyperuricemia and hepatotoxicity. It does not cause hypothyroidism or thyroid enlargement.

questions.text: The image below shows the life cycle of a virus. Which of the following drugs acts at step 5?
questions.solution:
• In the given image, step 5 represents the integration of the viral DNA into the host genome. This step is crucial for the virus to establish a persistent infection.
  • Raltegravir belongs to a class of antiviral drugs called integrase inhibitors. It inhibits the integration of viral DNA into the host genome by targeting the viral integrase enzyme. Therefore, raltegravir acts at step 5

Enfuvirtide (Option B) is a fusion inhibitor. It prevents the virus from entering the host cell by blocking the fusion of the viral envelope with the host cell membrane, acting at Step 2 of the viral life cycle.

Tenofovir (Option C) is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI). It blocks the reverse transcription of viral RNA into DNA, acting at Step 3 of the viral cycle.

Zidovudine (Option D) is also a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI). It blocks the reverse transcription of viral RNA into DNA, acting at Step 3 of the viral cycle.

Learning Objective:

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presented to the psychiatry outpatient department (OPD) exhibiting symptoms of hypomania. She has a previous history of a manic episode. Currently, she is considering pregnancy. Which medication should be avoided due to its high teratogenic potential for the developing fetus?
questions.solution:
• Valproate (valproic acid) is known to have a high teratogenic potential and should be avoided in women who are planning pregnancy.
  • It is associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects (such as spina bifida) and other congenital malformations if used during pregnancy.
  • Valproate (valproic acid) is an anticonvulsant and mood-stabilizing medication primarily used to treat epilepsy and bipolar disorder, which is highly teratogenic and is contraindicated in pregnancy and in women of childbearing age.

Lithium (Option B) is also associated with some risks, particularly cardiac malformations (like Ebstein's anomaly, about 1 in 1000, a rare congenital heart defect). However, the risk of teratogenicity is lower compared to valproate.

Oxcarbazepine (Option C) is an anticonvulsant medication that is sometimes used to treat bipolar disorder. It is not known to be highly teratogenic, but there is limited data on its safety during pregnancy. It is generally considered to be safer than valproate and lithium.

Olanzapine (Option D) is an atypical antipsychotic that is generally considered to have a lower teratogenic risk compared to mood stabilizers like valproate.

Learning Objective:

Teratogenic Drugs:

  • Thalidomide
  • Epileptic drugs like Valproate & Phenytoin
  • Retinoid (Vitamin A)
  • ACEi & ARB
  • Lithium
  • OCP
  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol

Reference: NIH Link

questions.solution: • We can see that Drug 1 produces a higher response than Drug 4 at all concentrations and above the baseline.

choices.text: Haemophilus alters penicillin-binding protein sites, hence resistant to ampicillin.
Easier to administer IV ceftriaxone than IV ampicillin
Cotrimoxazole is the drug of choice, butthe patient is allergic to sulfa drugs
Hemophilus produces beta-lactamase, hence resistant to ampicillin

questions.text: What could be the likely cause for shifting the initial treatment plan of starting on ampicillin to ceftriaxone in a 14-month-old diagnosed with Haemophilus influenza meningitis?
questions.solution:
• The antibiotic was most likely changed from Ampicillin to Ceftriaxone.
  • Haemophilus produces beta-lactamas,e which renders Ampicillin, a beta-lactam antibiotic, ineffective.
  • Haemophilus is sensitive to second and third-generation cephalosporins such as Ceftriaxone, which has a very long half-life allowing once-daily dosing.
    • Dose of Ceftriaxone - 50mg/kg/dose given 12 hourly
  • Vancomycin + Ceftriaxone is used as empirical therapy for suspected cases of meningitis beyond the neonatal period.

Hemophilus alters penicillin-binding protein sites, hence resistant to ampicillin (Option A). This statement is false as Hemophilus produces beta-lactamases which makes them resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics.

Easier to administer IV ceftriaxone than IV ampicillin (Option B ) as a single dose administration of ceftriaxone may be more convenient than the multiple daily doses required for ampicillin, but ease of administration is not the primary reason for switching from Ampicillin to Ceftriaxone.

Cotrimoxazole is the drug of choice, but the patient is allergic to sulfa drugs (Option C) Cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) is an antibiotic that is often used to treat Hemophilus influenzae infections. However, if the patient is allergic to sulfa drugs, cotrimoxazole may not be a suitable treatment option but in this patient, this is not the reason forthe change of ampicillin to ceftriaxone as there is no history of allergy to sulfa drugs.
